topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Create Your First Docker App

section.p: This Helion Development Platform release introduces the ability to deploy Docker images. This example takes an existing app and creates a Docker image that will run in ALS and take advantage of the provisioned services.

section.title: Start With a New Stack
section.p: One of the advantages to using Docker is the ability to run different flavors of Linux. While ALS is based on Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, Docker images can be based on a different distro, such as Debian, CentOS, or even Alpine Linux images. This example uses the openSUSE base image.

Docker can compartmentalize system configuration into separate Docker layers, either by breaking up configuration steps into separate RUN directives in a single Dockerfile, or by creating separate images and chaining them together with the FROM directive at the top of each separate Dockerfile. This example includes both methods.

body.section:
Prerequisites For security, Docker container deployments are disabled. The organization administrator needs to explicitly enable container deployments. Before attempting to create Docker applications, ensure you have the following:
A DockerHub account.
On OSX you also need Boot2Docker installed and running. [Boot2Docker does not need sudo commands.]
On a Linux machine you also need Docker.

section.title: Update and Installing Operating System Packages
section.p: Create a Dockerfile with the content below. This Dockerfile executes an update using the package manager; on openSUSE, this is done with zypper.
section.codeblock:
FROM opensuse:13.2 MAINTAINER Troy Topnik <troyt@activestate.com>
RUN zypper -n up && zypper -n install python python-pip ca-certificates-mozilla vim git curl wget
section.p:
The openSUSE base image is intentionally minimal, so this also installs:
python Required for a Python web app
python-pip For installing Python dependencies
ca-certificates-mozilla Required by pip to use SSL
vim Editor
git For cloning repos or installation from git sources
curl For general HTTP testing wgetFor fetching of potentially useful things.

These installations provide the tools that are most likely necessary to script the installation of a Python application, try things out interactively in a locally running Docker container, or troubleshoot apps (through an ssh session).

Notice that a couple of commands were chained together in the RUN statement. Every time a RUN command is used in a Dockerfile, it generates another image layer, and there's a hard limit of 127 layers in the current versions of Docker (the AUFS default limit). Bundling related commands together reduces the number of layers, helping ensure that the maximum is not exceeded. If there are relatively few layers, having the update and package install steps in separate RUN commands can take advantage of Docker's ability to use cached layers when rebuilding, which can speed up the build significantly.

section.title: Build, test, and push Docker Images

In this case, --no-cache is used to ensure that the zypper update runs each time it builds, rather than relying on the cached image layer from previous builds.
After the build completes, open an interactive shell and verify that it went as expected:
section.codeblock: sudo docker run -i -t troytop/opensuse-python /bin/sh sh-4.2# pip -V pip 1.5 from /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages (python 2.7) sh-4.2# exit

body.section:
Create an Application Container: bottle-currency-suse
First, clone the Docker version of the example app (bottle-currency). This app is based on Ubuntu 12.04, so the Dockerfile can be adapted to work with an opensuse-python image.
git clone https://github.com/Stackato-Apps/bottle-currency.git
Once the project is cloned, create a Docker file using the following the steps:FROM <myrepo>/opensuse-python MAINTAINER <myname> <myemail>Use a different container as a starting point and identify yourself as the maintainer. RUN useradd -d /home/www -m -s /bin/bash www USER www WORKDIR /home/wwwThis creates a new user called www and sets the active user and the working directory.For maximum security, no app should run as root unless absolutely necessary.COPY . . Since the Dockerfile exists in the base directory of the bottle-currency sources, this command will recursively copy the contents of the current directory into the WORKDIR defined above. RUN pip install --user -r requirements.txt This installs the modules required by the application. With a staged application, this part would be handled by the buildpack instead. EXPOSE 8080Without a $PORT environment variable, apps default to running on port 8080. This command EXPOSEs the default port in the container so that it's routed to an external port on the DEA host. The ALS router will in turn be able to route to the app by forwarding external requests to this hostname:port.
With Docker Apps, only one port must be exposed. When running a staged app, the application code or the Procfile would have to reference the $PORT variable provided in the container.CMD python wsgi.pyThis command starts the web process. In a staged app, this would be specified in a Procfile. Now that the Dockerfile is ready, the next step is to create, test and push the image.repeat the same steps used for the opensuse-python image to build, test, and push the image.
To build it, run this command in a directory that is empty except for the Dockerfile:$ sudo docker build --no-cache -t <myrepo>/bottle-currency-suse .Assuming all work was done on localhost, connecting to http://localhost:8000 with a browser will show the running web app, but the error message "An error occurred while contacting the server" will appear. The conversion app does not function yet because it requires a Redis data service.
Push the new image to the Docker Hub: sudo docker push <myrepo>/bottle-currency-suse

Deploying the App
The bottle-currency app looks for a Redis data service exposed by a REDIS_URL environment variable. Environment variables (VCAP_SERVICES) are injected into the Docker containers to provide connection information for any services that have been bound to the app. This is the 12-Factor method, which has always been standard practice for Cloud Foundry. Deploy the app with the following command:helion push -n --docker-image <myrepo>/bottle-currency-suse --mem 128 --as docker-currencyThis fetches the Docker image from the Hub and deploys it, but without a database.There are a number of ways to parse environment variables when connecting to the data services. If you are deploying a Docker image written by a third party, the credentials provided by ALS will need to be reformatted into variables that the app can understand. To do this, add another layer on top of the third-party image which parses the provided environment variables, reformats them in a way the app will understand, and reiterates the CMD / ENTRYPOINT line from the original image.
